29612751.review:
[i]Disclosure: I backed this game on Indiegogo. One of the developers recently friended me on Steam, but I don't know them outside the context of bug reporting.[/i]

On one hand, [i]Angels with Scaly Wings[/i] is a slice of life comedy about hanging out with dragons in their suspiciously humanlike society doing things like getting drunk, playing video games, and going on a scavenger hunt for pizza coupons. On the other hand, it's a mystery where you're trying to track down a serial killer and prevent the apocalypse, and even the good endings are somewhat bittersweet. In some ways, though, that incongruity worked for me, creating an atmosphere where the serious parts weren't too heavy and I was willing to suspend my disbelief for the more handwavey sci-fi elements.

The art's inconsistent, as well. It's pretty common for character sprites and CGs to be drawn by different artists and even in a different style, but the decision to introduce characters with their CGs before showing their sprites makes the contrast rather jarring. The amount of artwork is nice, including character sprites for even minor roles and bonus artwork that unlocks when you reach certain scenes and endings, but I wish there was also a gallery for the in-game CGs.

Spoilers for story structure: [spoiler]the story is based on a time loop, where you must use the knowledge you gained from previous loops to affect events in this one. Blurring the line between the protagonist's perspective and the player's metagame knowledge of characters and events is an effective way to justify unlockable choices and paths, so even though it might be an overused premise for visual novels, I like it and I don't care.[/spoiler]

There's more gameplay than the average VN, with lots of dialogue options in conversations, story choices, and a few random minigames. You can skip read text with the tab key or use a menu option to jump past entire scenes you've already viewed, which makes replaying to find all the endings and secrets a lot less frustrating than it might have been. As a fast reader, it took me a little over 10 hours to get all the endings and most of the achievements, and with the exception of one event [spoiler](that stupid sphere in the park)[/spoiler] I found it easy to see the way characters and events interacted across routes and figure out what to do without a guide.

Unfortunately it looks like the demo is no longer available due to changes in the final version, so I'd suggest checking out some gameplay videos on YouTube. If you like the characters, the feels you get will probably be enough to let you overlook the game's flaws. If not, you'll probably just find it annoying.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I’m not going to make a secret out of this since everyone who achieves their first ending can find my name in the credits. I was partially “involved” in the game creation process, providing some idea input and beta testing. However, I’m not financially involved in this project (besides funding it during the Indiegogo campaign). So, this review is based purely on my personal point of view, I also keep it [u]Spoiler free[/u].

[b] tl;dr version for anyone in a hurry: [/b]
I would recommend this game for anyone who is looking for a nice story with a quite unique touch. I personally really enjoyed the mix of scientific & slice of life aspects. 
The characters appear authentic to me. The main story was thrilling due to the healthy mix of casual storytelling and drama and the conclusion (or let’s say “true ending”) was very satisfying. 
Overall, be prepared for an emotional rollercoaster ride (if you are willing to sink into the story), I can confirm that you can spend at least 10h into this game, but it’s 10h well spend.

[b] Longer version: [/b]

[i]Foreword[/i]

Well, by now I’ve spend about 48h into this game, due to extended beta testing and protocolling. I can say, this was a handful. 
I’m a great fan of Indie games, however, a visual novel is relatively new to me. Therefore, I’ve ended up giving in to the story, maybe more than I could initially handle. However, it was an experience I would like to repeat (and please do not recommend Clannad that’s something I’ve already covered)

[i]Artistic design[/i]

Overall, I was satisfied with the mix of artistic elements. I usually pull music & art together since they generally synchronize in videogames and create a holistic impression. I personally liked the music It was quite fitting in most occasions, not boring over time and changed & transitioned with a healthy pace. 
I also liked the overall art design, I can imagine that it’s quite a challenge to get facial expressions for something like dragons but I feel like it worked out well in the end. Unfortunately, one thing I’ve realized after showing this game to a friend, the art assets are relatively limited and re-cycle a lot. It’s nothing really bothering me, since I know that Indies with smaller teams are usually limited in their resources, but some people might think differently.
However, my personal concern about this would be mainly the fact that some backgrounds appeared to be rather “odd”. For instance, while some buildings appeared to be ok in the setting, others, well… I know its canon but some background choices were too “human” (weird to say). Thankfully, the irritation is not consistent and only a smaller subject.

[i]Storytelling[/i]

As mentioned before. I greatly enjoyed the storytelling. The story transition was fitting and not too irritating. I also really liked the individual character design. I felt like every character had their own specific personality and a broad variety of characteristic dimensions. Overall, it was pleasant interacting with each main character. I was also able to feel into their story and understand their motives and viewpoints. Unfortunately for me, this also amplified the drama factor.
I’ve perceived the story as very thrilling in general, I basically soaked up every different story path.
However, I eventually felt like I got stuck at a certain point. I don’t want to spoil it but I can only recommend you to explore different paths and don’t try to continuously focus on one character.
Be aware that in order to find the “true ending” you might encounter a point where the story telling “drops” and you find yourself skipping a lot. I’m not sure if this is some common element of visual novels, but something I’ve noticed towards the end.
I’ve also ended up, being really confused during this game. And I mean “clusterfuck” level confusion. All I can say, Its normal, Its part of the reward.

[i]Conclusion[/i]

Overall, it was quite a story experience. Something I would recommend, not necessarily to all my friends. But to people who like to see something different for a change, like emotional & drama rich stories (or just adore dragons). I think this VN is something quite unusual and I respect the people behind this for having the guts to push it until the end. It was a fun experience and worth the price of a movie ticket.

Ok here’s a Review from some who has beaten all of Angels with Scaly Wings (well apart from a few minor things I haven’t experienced yet). I will keep this review spoiler free.

- Game Overview -
First of all what is it? - Angels with Scaly Wings is a Visual Novel (Interactive story if you are unfamiliar with the term) where you are a human ambassador sent through a portal to a world filled with dragons. You are there to ensure the deals and negotiations between the the races go smoothly. You make decisions and hang on as mysteries arise and the relationships you make with your new friends, enemies and… frenemies? become the one thing you know you can rely on.
Also yes you can date dragons if you want but you don’t have to. (I mean it’s a visual novel it’s practically the law you have to be able to date someone in one.) You can stay just friends with them but in my opinion if you do you are missing out.

- Music -
The soundtrack is really good. There was a track that I liked from the earlier demos that while I don’t think it made into the final game (I may have missed it) is still in the soundtrack with the deluxe edition! I can’t think if at any times when the music detracted from what was going on and it was definitely enjoyable to listen to and helped set the mood appropriately.

- Art -
The art is really nice, if you want to look at some visually distinct and appealing dragons then you won’t go wrong here. Each dargon has a few expressions and they help flesh out the conversations and show how they feel. The quality of the art varies a little bit, the new art seems a little nicer than the older art but it’s not an issue just something I noticed. It’s all still really nice.

- Characters -
The characters are all really interesting, they are all unique and complex. It is a really well crafted world. You might meet a dragon and know what they are like as an acquaintance but only through either spending time with them or someone else will you find out what drives them and why they act as they do. This means you will not necessarily learn everything about a character in one playthrough, even if you are pursuing their route or not.

- Plot -
I can’t talk about the plot without spoiling things, so I will keep this brief. I found the plot engaging, at times tense and while it would be tedious to replay sections you have seen before there is an option to skip sections you have seen before so multiple runs through the story are a breeze.
I should also mention that each characters story is compelling, None of them feel similar even though each character has interweaving stories. It just works to sell the whole thing as a narrative that you navigate through one piece at time set in what feels like a world that never takes a break even if you do. Each character has unique personalities with their own ambitions and troubles that you find out as you get to know them.

-Length -
In terms of length, a single playthrough wont take you very long (depending on how quickly you read), I wish it was a little longer in that regard but with so much replayability it will take a while before you can see everything, I mean there are one or two things I haven’t seen yet despite having completed every major characters story to completion. So I have no complaints about the overall length, it will keep you busy for a good while, I guess I just wish you could spend more with each dragon in a single playthrough.

-System Requirements -
I should also mention that because it is a Visual Novel it will run on basically any hardware - pretty much if you can read this review you can play it for yourself! (Unless you using the steam app on your phone (I think you can read reviews on it I’m not sure though) but I have heard rumours of an android port of the game in the future so who knows!)

- Final Thoughs -
Overall it’s a quality experience and as a backer of the Indiegogo campaign it’s great to have finally played it. The team behind it have delivered in full. It is the complete package that is above what was promised from the goals outlined in the campaign. I fully recommend it. It was thrilling yes but also quite dark at times. Also consider the deluxe edition - you get the full soundtrack (Jammin’), a making of PDF (Historical), a fair bit of artwork (C'est ne pas un dragon) and things like backgrounds and icons (Accessorise!)

I also want to finally have a quick shout out to all involved with making Angels with Scaly Wings to say thanks for a great game. (And thank you to the other backers for helping to fund it) I thoroughly enjoyed it and I can’t wait to hear more news from the Devs, whether it be more about our dragon friends (Haha) or new projects.

So, after completing 7 of the ending I feel that it is time for me to write a review on this game. Overall, I would have to say this is a phenominal game, one that is very unique and has a story that is fairly original compared to what we see now adays. I know many of you have read this before, but I bought this game as a joke with some friends, assuming that it would just be some weird dragon fetish dating sim(which dont get me wrong, it has those sexual elements in the game, but it isnt as exagerated as I would have thought.) After my first ending, which took me around 3 hours, I could not get enough of this game, and every story brought happiness, while nearly every ending brought pain and sadness. This journey sends you on a rollercoaster of emotions, and hits you with some twists here and there, and as a whole, I believe that this game had passion and care put behind it.

(THERE WILL BE SOME SPOILERS BELOW, NOTHING MAJOR)

Overall there are 13+ endings(the extra one is a little secret), a good and bad ending for each of the 5 main characters, and then a true, bad and neutral ending. While as you can guess, the bad ending end up with pain and emotional stress, you may not think that many of the good ending send you on a heart wrenching journey full of sadness and emotional trauma. Each of the characters are unique in their own ways, and you truly feel that each one is perfectly hand crafted in order to make this game come to life. While I had heard many negative comments about the true ending, which I feel came from the lack of more, we all want to see happily ever after, but this game only makes you long for more content and interaction. At the end, it tells you to keep your save files for future use, which makes me hope and believe that there will be something more to this game, other than the secret true ending(which is just a slight modification to the original true ending). There are a few side characters, some that you can go on a single date with, some you cannot, and while I would really love to see more about them, as some are very interesting, you cant expect everything from a game with little funding and a small team.

Now keeping in mind that this game only received around $12000 dollars in funding at the end of the Indiegogo campaign, and with that small amount of money(and I assume some personal resources), the creator, M.B Saunders, has crafted something that will go down as one of the most unique and meaningful games I have ever played. In the future, I hope to see what can become of this story, and if the future holds something even greater than this game. When you look into this, you can tell that this was not some kind of money grab, or scam, but a passion project that took passion to create, and today, we dont see this kind of love very often.

The art for this game could have been better, but there are some illustrated pieces that are a great addition, and the gallery offers images of the various characters that you meet throughout the game, some of which I have chosen to keep as a wallpaper for my computer. The backdrops for the game are fairly well made for a game like this, some are drawn and some seem 3-D modeled, but overall, they fit with the style very well, and help to add atmosphere to the game. The music choice here is wonderful, it adds to the overall ambiance of the game, and the atmosphere it helps to construct is beautiful, and the sadness that it can bring is also phenominal(although the sadness h u r t s).

Now, this game is not for everyone of course, and if the dating sim and inuendos were removed, I feel this could be great story by itself, although without the in depth character interaction the game would seem lacking. There are many paths to choose, some will be great sadness, and some will leave you feeling touched(sometimes literally *wink wink*), but in the end, it is up to you what path you will choose on this great adventure that has been set before you.

I didn't have high expectations for this game. I saw the reviews, everyone said it was great, but I was cynical.
However, being the furry trash that I am, I decided to just go for it and buy the game while it was on sale.

I do not regret this decision.
First and foremost, let me make this clear: This game is not a dating sim, and there isn't any truly lewd content (aside from occasional, questionably flirty text options. No visuals for sure.)

This game has a plot, a story, and a setting, and a damn fucking good one at that. It answers almost every question I've had, and even blows away my initial criticisms. To start with (Potential spoilers):
The opening intro seems heavily cliche'd and rather meh. You're given a simple explanation: Sci-fi future for humanity, humanity finds portal, portal leads to land of anthropomorphic dragons that speak English and have a human-esque society. Seems really coincidental huh? I thought so to... But it's not. My very first criticisms were as follows:
A: The backgrounds of every scene include human furniture, chairs and such, that very clearly wouldn't be compatible with these draconic species. It'd be awfully uncomfortable to sit down on a human chair with a massive tail behind you, or with four legs.
B: The rest of the dragon society isn't very dragon-efficient at all. (Most of my criticisms in general were about the sheer convenience of it all)

Guess fucking what?
The cheeky dev did this on purpose. There's an actual explanation. This isn't a dumb game made by someone that overlooked a common cliche that most modern media producers fall for as well.

Cleverly enough, you aren't told the full story at the beginning. Not even of yourself, or humanity's current condition... You have to learn it by playing futher into the game. And some things, you can't learn without playing it again. The game delves deep into discussions about teleportation, philosophy, time and space, a lot of scientific sh*t I for sure wasn't expecting- and it doesn't do so incompetently. The story is incredibly rich, the options are varied, the choices you make change A LOT of factors, the writing is intelligent and I've only spotted one grammatical error after multiple playthroughs. The few minigames/puzzles that are included are short and entertaining, and don't feel lazily hamfisted into the game. 
Most importantly though, the characters are all three-dimensional (figuratively speaking). They all have motives, pros and cons. Even characters that can initially be characterized as stereotypes aren't necessarily so. The personalities are varied, they act coincidentally human. There's twists and turns about each and every person, how they act, why they do it. It's shockingly well-crafted, it's clear that whoever made this put a lot of love and effort into making their visual novel a genuine visual novel, not just some sappy fantasy story to appease those who have interests in non-human characters.

All-in-all, I'd give this game a good 8/10 for what it's trying to accomplish, I'm pleasantly surprised. 
I typically justify a game's price by hours in enjoyment. If I can spend at least thirty minutes to an hour enjoying myself per $2, I feel satisfied. For $10 (Although I bought this on sale, mind you), I feel the game is well worth it's price. There were a few moments where I was bored, but the majority of my current playtime and future playtime (I'm still playing it now!) have been mostly enjoyable, and it's definitely one of those games that you quite simply can't stop thinking about, once you're done playing. I've had it on my mind for a while now, even during breaks and such. If you don't like visual novels, the game probably isn't made for you, but as someone who's generally indifferent towards them, I'm extremely pleased!

Edit: For the record, nobody is the bad guy. People will shit talk each other like Anna, Emera, and Reza especially, but when you get to know characters... You learn to understand their motives, why they do things. They all have a reason for it, they all have a reason to be considered the 'good guy', and yet you can blame them for ethical wrongs all the same. There is no clear good guy or bad guy, it's all based on what you think and choose.
